title: about me
text:
I am a multidisciplinary researcher with expertise in both wet lab and computational techniques, working extensively in the processing and analysis of human clinical samples.
I was born in a small village in Bihar, India. My research journey began during my bachelor’s studies at Anugrah Narayan College, Patna, where I formed lasting friendships and developed a keen interest in science. Together with friends, I embarked on Master’s degree in Animal Biotechnology at the University of Hyderabad. It was during this time, inspired by the cutting-edge genomics facility at the School of Life Sciences, that I developed a strong interest in genomics.
To pursue my interest, I did PhD from the Laboratory of Molecular Oncology at the Centre for DNA Fingerprinting and Diagnostics (CDFD), Hyderabad. My doctoral research focused on early-onset sporadic rectal cancer (EOSRC), where I developed a growing interest in organoids model and T cells mediated immunopathogenesis.
Following my research at CDFD, I moved to Queen Mary University of London, where I followed my research interests and generated organoids from different regions of the mouse oral cavity and established Organoids – T cell co-culture systems.
Currently at Barts Liver Centre, I am investigating the immunopathogenesis of early-stage Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatohepatitis (MASH). My research focuses on profiling the T cell repertoire and its functional responses in early-stage MASH.
Beyond the lab, I am deeply committed to science communication and education, and I actively engage with students and broader communities to share knowledge and inspire curiosity in biomedical science.

title: Raju Kumar
text: I am an enterprising biomedical research scientist dedicated to dissect the role of T cells in disease outcomes. My current research focuses on understanding T cells involvement in the liver, adipose tissues, and blood of patients with early-stage liver fibrosis. Through this work, I aim to advance our understanding of the early-stage liver fibrosis drivers and contribute to the development of innovative therapeutic strategies.

title: research experience
text:
Postdoctoral Researcher
Queen Mary University of London, UK
November 2022 – Present
I am currently investigating the immunopathogenesis of Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatotic Liver Disease (MASLD), with a focus on understanding the mechanistic links between innate and adaptive immune cells across anatomical compartments during progressive stages of Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatohepatitis (MASH). In this project, we employ a multi-omics approach integrating CITE-seq and TCR-seq on CD45⁺ immune cells isolated from simultaneously collected liver, peripheral blood, subcutaneous, and visceral adipose tissues obtained during bariatric surgery. Furthermore, I perform high-dimensional spatial profiling using multiplex immunostaining (Cell DIVE™) on the same tissue specimens subjected to CITE-seq, enabling spatial validation and contextualisation of the single-cell transcriptomic data.
Postdoctoral Researcher
Queen Mary University of London, UK
November 2020 – November 2022
In this role, I investigated the functional and spatial intra-tumour heterogeneity in oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC), focusing on tumour–immune interactions that drive epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and tumour progression. We performed exome sequencing and deep immune phenotyping of early-stage lesions, invasive OSCC, and nodal metastases. In parallel, I established organoids from distinct anatomical regions of the mouse oral cavity and developed organoids-T cell co-culture models to study epithelial–immune cell interactions involving CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T cells.
Postdoctoral Researcher
Centre for DNA Fingerprinting and Diagnostics (CDFD), India
October 2018 – November 2020
I collaborated with pathologists to profile the immune landscape of rectal cancer through histological techniques including H&E staining, immunohistochemistry, and image analysis. In parallel, I contributed to characterising the gene fusion landscape in colorectal cancer by performing in silico functional analyses using bioinformatics tools. Shortlisted fusion candidates were subsequently validated through PCR amplification, Sanger sequencing, cloning, and in vitro functional assays.
Additionally, my research focused on elucidating the regulatory role of ARID1B, a component of the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodelling complex, in transcriptional control via enhancer–promoter looping. I employed ARID1B pull-down assays followed by mass spectrometry to identify interacting partners, and validated key enhancer–promoter interactions using ChIP-qPCR and ChIP-loop techniques.
Doctoral Researcher
Centre for DNA Fingerprinting and Diagnostics (CDFD), India
July 2012 – October 2018
My Ph.D. research focused on characterising unique molecular subtypes of early-onset sporadic rectal cancer (EOSRC), particularly cases lacking canonical Wnt/β-catenin pathway activation, which is prevalent in over half of Indian patients with EOSRC. Using gene expression microarrays, I compared Wnt-negative and Wnt-positive tumours and identified: (a) Enrichment of Ca²⁺/NFAT signalling in Wnt-negative tumours (b) An eight-gene transcriptional signature distinguishing Wnt-positive from Wnt-negative tumours (c) XPNPEP3 as a novel transcriptional target of the Wnt/β-catenin pathway
Master’s Research Project
University of Hyderabad, India
August 2010 – July 2012
I conducted a one-year dissertation project on the mechanisms of drug resistance in Leishmania donovani, focusing on Amphotericin B resistance in the amastigote stage. I identified differential isoform expression of S-Adenosyl-L-Methionine: C-24-Δ-Sterol Methyltransferase (SCMT) between wild-type and resistant strains.

Learned differential blood cell identification and various biochemical assays, including CRP, ESR, glucose, and hormone level assessments.

title: skills
text:
Omics
Proficient in sample preparation for whole exome seq, bulk RNA seq, single-cell RNA-seq, CITE-seq, and TCR-seq and its data analysis using R and Python.
Microscopy
Well seasoned in brightfield, phase-contrast, fluorescence, confocal, and multiplex tissue imaging. Experienced in Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and super-resolution microscopy.
Tissue Processing
Expert in macro-dissection of tumour epithelium, preparation of FFPE blocks, tissue sectioning, haematoxylin and eosin staining (H&E), immunohistochemistry, micro-dissection of epithelial tissue for DNA isolation, and primary tumour-derived cell line generation.
3D Cell Culture
Experienced in generating spheroids and organoids, isolating and culturing immune cells, and establishing organoid–immune cell co-culture systems.
2D Cell Culture
Skilled in the maintenance and manipulation of human cell lines, including drug treatment, cell viability assays, transfection, viral transduction, stable clone generation, immunofluorescence assays, migration and wound healing assays.
Microarray
Hands-on experience with array-based Comparative Genomic Hybridization (aCGH) and gene expression microarrays. Competent in R programming for data preprocessing, normalization, clustering, CMS, SAM, and GSEA. Skilled in using online tools and databases such as cBioPortal, Enrichr, UCSC Genome Browser (ENCODE), Gene Ontology, and WebGestalt.
Molecular Biology
Proficient in DNA and RNA isolation from blood, frozen, and FFPE tissues; and in techniques like mutation screening, denaturing urea PAGE, formaldehyde agarose gel electrophoresis, reverse transcription, quantitative PCR (qPCR), molecular cloning, site-directed mutagenesis, chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP), and luciferase reporter assays.
Protein Biology
Experienced in protein extraction and purification, dialysis, SDS and native PAGE, and Western blotting for protein analysis.
Infection Biology
Hands-on experience in culturing clinical isolates of Leishmania donovani, infecting human cell lines, and performing related assays including DNA fragmentation, Giemsa staining, CFSE and PI staining. Trained in Biosafety Level 2 (BSL-2) facility for SARS-CoV-2 diagnostics.
Model Organisms
Experienced in dissection and handling of BALB/cJ and C57BL/6J mice. Familiar with Drosophila melanogaster techniques through advanced training. Certified in “Basics of Mouse Genetics” and “Introduction to CRISPR/Cas9 and Cre-lox Technologies” from The Jackson Laboratory, USA.
Biostatistics and Epidemiology
Trained in clinical study design, collection and analysis of clinicopathological and survival data, hypothesis testing, and data visualization.
